p: Members of the genera Bromovirus and Cucumovirus are capable of producing the defective (d)RNAs and defective-interfering (di)RNAs during infection ( Table 1). In particular, strains of Broad bean mottle virus (BBMV) do accumulate RNA2-derived deletion variants after serial passages through broad bean. In BMV, both replicating and non-replicating truncated RNA2-derived artificial diRNAs have been shown to interfere with BMV RNAs in protoplasts. For CMV, several types of RNA3-derived diRNAs have been described.
